Steps.Description: Perform directory scan to discover /cmd.php endpoint.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker is trying to identify potential vulnerabilities in the web application.
StepDetails.Action: Scan the web application's directory structure to find hidden or accessible endpoints.

Steps.Description: Analyze the code of cmd.php and identify the blacklist filter.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker wants to understand the blacklist filter to find ways to bypass it.
StepDetails.Action: Review the code of cmd.php and analyze the blacklist filter logic.
StepDetails.Result: The blacklist filter is identified, containing characters and keywords to be filtered.

Steps.Description: Attempt to perform command injection using the discovered blacklist filter.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker believes that the blacklist filter can be bypassed to execute arbitrary commands.
StepDetails.Action: Craft a command injection payload and attempt to execute commands using the /cmd.php endpoint.
StepDetails.Result: The blacklist filter prevents the execution of certain commands.
StepDetails.FailingReason: The blacklist filter effectively filters out certain characters and keywords.

Steps.Description: Use base64-encoded payload to bypass the blacklist filter.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker believes that encoding the payload in base64 can bypass the blacklist filter.
StepDetails.Action: Encode the desired command in base64 and construct a command to execute the decoded payload.
StepDetails.Result: The base64-encoded payload successfully bypasses the blacklist filter and executes the desired command.
